awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Geographic, Socio-economic, and Cultural Factors Shaping Crop Diversity and Livelihood Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. It has both  scientific and societal benefits in addition to integrating research and education. Relationships between on-farm crop diversity and food and income security have long been of interest to scholars and development practitioners. The REU Site at the University of Vermont (UVM) provides eight U.S. students from diverse backgrounds an opportunity to conduct interdisciplinary research on crop diversity and livelihoods among smallholder farmers. Under the eight-week REU, students spend four weeks on the UVM campus in Burlington, Vermont where they train in spatial analysis, survey analysis using existing large farm and household datasets, qualitative research methods, and written and oral communication. They then conduct original research on on-farm crop diversity, regional crop diversity, nutrition, and rural livelihoods. Students thus have the chance to contribute to multi-dimensional research while developing theoretical and methodological skills, and engaging in cross-cultural partnerships. Building on the model of a previous REU Site, this program provides participants with a unique cultural and educational experience, while offering the chance to conduct original research in a supportive REU setting. Recruitment is open to any NSF eligible undergraduate students, though the program is designed to promote participation by low-income students, first generation college students, and students from underrepresented groups.

This REU Site contributes to active scholarly debates around how production of diverse crops relates to food and income security. Working with mentors from UVM, the National Socio-Environmental Synthesis Center (SESYNC), Pennsylvania State University, Sterling College, and the international research center Bioversity International, REU participants actively engage in the design and implementation of research on crop diversity and livelihoods across geographic scales including: (i) Geographic Information Systems (GIS) analyses using public and commercial datasets; (ii) statistical analyses using large, nationally representative household surveys (e.g., DHS, LSMS-ISA); and (iii) field-based surveys and interviews, working with local partners to verify findings from secondary data and further explore how crop and food choices relate to geographic, economic and cultural factors. We also provide innovative methods linking newly available geospatial datasets and large household survey datasets, and testing patterns that emerge from secondary analyses via primary data collection with local partners. Results are disseminated widely through meetings of community partners, a customized website, co-authored student publications in economics, rural sociology and interdisciplinary journals, and student participation in professional conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through a collaborative effort by the Department of Community Development and Applied Economics (CDAE) at the University of Vermont (UVM), the international agricultural research center Bioversity International, and partners at the University of Tennessee-Knoxville and at Sterling College in Craftsbury, Vermont, each summer from 2021-2023 this REU Site provided 8 American undergraduate students from diverse academic backgrounds an opportunity to conduct interdisciplinary research on crop diversity, food security, and livelihood outcomes in East Africa. Under the eight-week summer REU program students received training at Sterling College and the University of Vermont in social survey research design and methods, spatial analysis using Geographic Information Systems (GIS), and written and oral communication. They then worked with mentors from UVM, the University of Tennessee, Bioversity International, and other academic and government institutions to conduct research on crop diversity – at local / regional scales – and livelihoods among smallholder farmers.

Intellectual Merit:

All 24 REU Site Participants completed independent research projects, as well as contributing to interdisciplinary "framework projects" with group data collection and analysis spanning multiple years. Working closely with REU faculty mentors and partners at Sterling College, the University of Tennessee, and in Uganda, REU Site Participants actively engaged in the design and implementation of studies including:

Social and economic studies consisting of analysing farm and household survey data exploring factors associated with adoption of sustainable agricultural practices and with on- and off-farm income diversification strategies;

Geospatial analyses including analyses of climatic factors associated with farm livelihood strategies as well as the impacts of conflict on rural communities using open-source Geographic Information Systems (GIS) tools and diverse data sources ranging from recent United States Geological Survey satellite imagery, to survey-based World Bank Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS) data; and

Qualitative analyses of farm livelihood strategies including farm, household, and policy factors contributing to small-scale farm and pastoralist livelihoods and resilience.

All 24 REU Site Participants delivered at least one oral or poster presentation at a local, regional, national, or international conference through the program, in addition to other presentations at student conferences, public presentations to community partners, and results sharing at conferences including the Rural Sociological Society (RSS) Annual Meeting and the International Consortium on Applied Bioeconomy Research (ICABR) Conference.

Two graduate theses emerged from work initiated under the REU, as well as two undergraduate theses by REU Site Participants. Four peer-reviewed papers were published with REU students as lead- or co-authors.

Broader Impacts:

The REU site successfully recruited and expanded participation among traditionally underrepresented groups in the STEM fields; of the 24 REU Site Participants, over half were from underrepresented groups, and over half self-identified as female. Exit interviews and continuing correspondence suggest the training and fieldwork program ignited a passion for research in several students, especially among those with limited prior access to research opportunities or international travel experience. The program also helped develop a broad research network for REU Site Participants, including a community across REU Site cohorts, with former REU students returning to the University of Vermont to share their projects and their experiences with the new incoming cohort each year. Surveys and independent evaluations of the program repeatedly highlighted such opportunities for peer-mentoring - in addition to the extraordinary opportunity to engage in data collection and analysis in collaboration with student, faculty, and community partners in Uganda - as key strengths of the program. More broadly, the student research undertaken through this REU has provided additional evidence highlighting the need for interdisciplinary approaches to better understand, and better support, community-based approaches for enhancing agricultural productivity and food security.
